title: Does Your Child Understand Math or Just Memorize It?
description: How to tell the difference between genuine math understanding and rote memorization, and why it matters.

content.intro: Your child gets correct answers on homework. But do they understand why? The difference between understanding and memorization determines long-term math success.

items: New concepts build on old ones

sections.text: Understanding is transferable. Memorization is fragile.

rows: Gets answer but can't explain why
Doesn't notice when answer doesn't make sense
Can't tell if answer is reasonable

sections.text: "Why did you do that step?" A child who understands can explain. A memorizer says "because that's how you do it."
Can they solve 23×4 if they've practiced 23×3? Flexible application shows understanding.
"About how much is 48×12?" If they can't estimate (around 500-600), they may not understand the magnitude of the operation.
Can they identify what operation to use when given a word problem instead of just numbers?
"Can you teach me how to do this?" Teaching requires deep understanding.
A child who says "I just know it" for basic facts is fine – that's automaticity. But for procedures and concepts, "I just do it this way" suggests memorization without understanding.

items: Use physical objects and visual models
Praise process and reasoning, not just answers
Ask questions rather than giving answers

faq.question: Is memorization ever okay?
faq.answer: Yes – for basic facts (7×8=56), memorization is efficient and necessary. But for procedures and concepts, understanding should come first or alongside memorization.

faq.question: My child has been memorizing successfully. Will they hit a wall?
faq.answer: Possibly. Many kids do fine with memorization through early grades but struggle when math becomes more abstract (around 4th-6th grade) and requires flexible thinking.

faq.question: How do I help if they've only memorized?
faq.answer: Go back to foundational concepts with manipulatives and visual models. It may feel like going backward, but building understanding is essential for future progress.

cta.text: SoroKid emphasizes understanding through visual soroban methods, not just memorization of procedures.
